STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 28, 2022
Jodi Shinn
Ennis Center for Children Inc
20100 Greenfield Road
Detroit, MI 48235
RE: License #: CB740315326
Ennis Center for Children - Port Huron
222 Huron Avenue
Port Huron, MI 48060
Dear Ms. Shinn:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
03/22/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3012
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
In one out of six foster children records reviewed, there was no
documentation that the foster child had a physical examination every 14
months. The physical examination was missing from the record.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED INTERIM 2021
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
In one out of six foster children records reviewed, the updated services
plan dated 10/31/21 – 1/28/22 was generated on 2/16/2022. It was
nineteen days late.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS
MiSACWIS
(Commitment
22)
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (MiSACWIS) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
4

The following information required for this audit was not uploaded into MiSACWIS
timely or was missing:
Foster Home reevaluation
Initial medical examination
Closing foster care DHS 6b
Parent agency treatment plan
Child adoption assessment
Timely signatures from the doctor on medical documents
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings
FOM 722-6B -
page 2
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
• Case service plan development,
• permanency goal changes,
• placement preservation/disruption
• permanency planning at six months in care annual transition
planning for youth every six months from age 16 until case
closure
• 90-day discharge planning for youth
• Case closure
In one out of six case records reviewed, one was missing the FTM dated for
the reporting period 10/31/21 - 1/28/22.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver
Page 2
The individual activities required by the foster
parent/caregiver to meet the specific individual needs of
the child placed in their home are included in the PATP.
The foster parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP
process. The foster parent/caregiver signature is required
and indicates that the foster parent/caregiver
acknowledges and agrees to the activities required to meet
the needs of the child in their care. Additionally, the PATP
details the services and activities provided by the foster
5

care worker to assist the foster parent/caregiver in caring
for the child.
In one of six open foster care records reviewed, the PATP reporting period was
generated 09/29/21 -12/27/21 and was signed on 02/22/22. The signature was
more than 30 days following the service plan/PATPA’s approval date.
Policy FOM 722- Foster care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
8 E
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MISACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change:
Case Closure:
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
In one out of six case records reviewed , one did not show
documentation of a DHS 69 for the child’s 08/23/21 return home.
DHHS Policy Child Adoption Assessment
ADM 300
The DHS – 127, Child Adoption Assessment, must be
completed by the adoption worker and approved by the
adoption supervisor within 45 calendar days of case
acceptance. The adoption worker must verify that the
information provided through the foster care DHS – 65, Initial
Service Plan (ISP) and DHS -66 Updated Service Plan
(USP), is correct and include all additional information
required on the assessment form. Prior to completing the
child adoption assessment, the adoption worker must make
a minimum of two face-to face with the child’s current
caregiver, even if the caregiver (s) are not interested in
adopting the child. The contacts must be documented in the
child assessment.
In one out of eight adoption records reviewed, the child adoption assessment
was not completed timely. The case was accepted on 11/04/21, the
assessment was completed on 01/19/2022 and was more than 45 days late.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
6

DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings
FOM 722-6B -
page 2
All FTM meetings should invite all professionals, parents, foster parents, who
are included with the child’s case for case planning. This information should
be recorded in MiSACWIS.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver
Page 2
All foster parents on a license is required to sign the PATP for the child in
care.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Unannounced home visits needs to be documented in the updated service plans.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency received a special investigation that was initiated on 10/07/21. The CAP
was approved on 02/10/22. The agency was found in violation with rules 206, 207, 214
and FOM policies 722-6H and 722-8E. The agency is currently working on their CAP
and it will be verified within the required timeframe.
7

The agency submitted a CAP for their 06/04/21 Interim Inspection.
During the inspection entrance meeting, the chief administrator submitted her annual
assessment that detailed the barriers and systemic factors that have impacted
compliance during this assessment period. She reported the pandemic, worker
turnover/termination of employment, management turnover, lack of monitoring by
supervisors, the amount of policy changes/requirements and balancing quality as well
as quantity or work required. She reported additional training is needed on policies to
assist the newer staff in understanding the importance of documentation and fulfilling
the requirements necessary to complete their task.
The staff and supervisor interviewed reported no concerns with the program. They all
indicated they were committed to their employment and was during the best they
could to support the children and families in which they serve. They reported the
agency works well together and they feel supported by their coworkers and the
administration.
V1. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS:
There were no identified safety concerns.
V11. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that Ennis for Children – Port
Huron will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
03/28/2022
________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 29, 2022
